lines.text: His Master's voice...

[in opera house box]
In his autumn 'fore the winter comes man's last mad surge of youth
What on earth are you talking about?
You do look a little like Grandpa.

[Sadly]
I feel a lot like Grandpa. You know I think Grandpa has the right idea being a drunkard.

[to his niece Abigail]
And you, young lady, had better be singing in the opera tonight or we'll all have to move to Wichita!
You took the words right out of my mouth. That's very unsanitary.

[At his dressing table putting on makeup for a performance]
Is she pretty, Ossifish?
Oh, magnifico!
Is she pretty as a soprano or is she pretty?
Very pretty.
[He kisses his fingers]
I try not to look at her.
Good!

[to Martha as she is about to go on stage]
Spunk up, kid! All they can do is throw things at ya.

[to his partners on stage]
You see, fellas? All you need is personality, money and good looks. I've got personality. I've got money...
[pauses]
Well, two out of three ain't bad.
If it's true, we're ruined. And what's more important, I'm ruined.
Oh, Uncle Jonathan. Hugo, are you sure he said Abigail?
Abigail. Your sister Abigail.
I don't believe it. Abigail is in New York but she'd never do a thing like... like...
He said she sang... in public?
He said she sang and danced in a low café in the Bowery. That's what he said, Aunt Jennifer.
That's a lie.
If it isn't, we're ruined socially.
Remember when Cousin Harriet ran off with the hurdy gurdy man? Oh, ho ho!
Cousin Harriet did not have an uncle running for mayor of Boston.
[Suddenly]
I have it! It's a political plot to ruin my campaign, that's what it is!
I see what it is. It's your rival.
It's that Wetherby. He started this slander.
He's no gentleman, Uncle Jonathan.
He's a... he's a... Democrat! I'll sue him for libel.
He should be put in jail!
Oh, I think it's most unfair.
I'll sue him for $100,000. That's what I'll do.
You never can tell. Little Abigail looked just like Cousin Harriet when she was a baby. Why they even said she looked like me!
Why, she does look like Grandpa. I'd forgotten.
You'll never keep Abigail in mothballs, believe me.
[He cackles]
Silence!

[Pointing to Abigail, he is drunk and forcibly escorted away]
She's the "Queen of Burlesque" with the Golden Rooster! She's "The Belle of the Bowery!"
Oh dear, dear. This is dreadful. This is really dreadful.
[to Abigail]
I'm so sorry.
Well, what's the matter with being "The Belle of the Bowery?" What's wrong with that?
There's nothing the matter with being "The Belle of the Bowery" Mr. Marengo except she's not the sort of a person we'd care to have in the opera.
Oh, you was thinkin' of her for the opera?
Miss Abigail has a very beautiful voice. I'm sure it was the alcohol in Wrigley that was talking, wasn't it Miss Abigail?

[Before Abigail can speak, Martha jumps in]
Oh, he meant me. I'm the one who sings at the Golden Rooster, not Abigail.
Martha, have you lost your mind?
I am High "C" Suzie.

[laughs nervously]
This is ridiculous. Abigail, what's gotten into her?
I'm sure that butler's been drinking.
Mr. Marengo, you know she's talking nonsense.

[to Martha]
Are you on the level, kid?
I'm "The Belle of the Bowery" and I'm proud of it.
Well, I... I refuse to believe it. I shall, if necessary, go down to, uh, the place and prove it all to be a fiction.
That might be best.
I shall be there tomorrow night.
I think it a very good idea.
